explanation:
Explain why each symbol is required to check for invariant controlling expressions:

- struct Request
  - The function reads and writes fields of struct Request (request, request->pp, request->session, request->post_url). Whether these fields are initially NULL, are updated by post-processing, or are modified by called helpers determines the truth values of control expressions (e.g., if (NULL == request), if (NULL == request->session), and the later url reassignment). The exact layout and semantics (types and names of these fields) are required to decide if the controlling expressions can change during the call or are effectively invariant.

- struct Session
  - request->session is tested and then used (session->start = time(NULL)). Knowing Session fields and whether get_session or other helpers can mutate session pointers or their contents is necessary to judge if the session-related tests are invariant.

- pages
  - The while loop and subsequent handler call iterate/search pages[] using pages[i].url and pages[i].handler. To know whether the loop condition (pages[i].url != NULL && strcmp(...)) can ever change or is constant, the contents, termination condition, and mutability of pages[] must be known.

- MHD_HTTP_METHOD_POST, MHD_HTTP_METHOD_GET, MHD_HTTP_METHOD_HEAD
  - The function compares the incoming method string against these constants. Their values (and whether any called code could overwrite method or these constants) determine whether those strcmp-based conditions are potentially invariant.

- get_session
  - Called to obtain/initialize request->session. Its behavior (returning NULL vs non-NULL, side effects on request or connection state) directly affects the if (NULL == request->session) test — whether it is always true/false or can change.

- MHD_create_post_processor
  - Called when setting up POST handling; it returns a post-processor stored in request->pp. Whether this call can fail or any side effects it performs matter to the control flow that follows (the early return and later POST processing). Understanding its semantics is necessary to decide if related conditions are invariant.

- MHD_post_process
  - This function processes upload_data and is the place where POST parsing may set request->post_url (or other request fields). Because request->post_url can change the url variable later (affecting which page is served), knowledge of MHD_post_process side effects is essential to determine whether subsequent controlling expressions (e.g., page selection) are invariant.

- MHD_destroy_post_processor
  - Called after POST data is complete; it may also run cleanup routines (post_process_urlencoded/free_unmarked) that affect request state. Those side effects can change later control expressions, so its behavior must be known.

- post_iterator
  - The post-processor is created with this callback; the callback is likely responsible for setting request fields (for example, request->post_url). To know whether POST processing makes later control expressions non-invariant, the callback’s semantics are needed.

- post_process_urlencoded, post_process_multipart
  - These are the routines actually invoked to parse POST payloads (per the static call graph). They likely modify request state (e.g., set post_url or mark fields). Their effects determine whether control expressions that rely on request or url values can change during execution.

(Notes)
- Standard library functions like strcmp and time are assumed to have usual semantics; they need not be included here unless their behavior is altered in this code base.
- Constants like MHD_YES/MHD_NO or METHOD_ERROR are not required to determine whether controlling expressions are invariant; they affect return values but not whether conditions are constant.

In short: to decide if any conditional or loop controlling expression in create_response is invariant, we must know the layout and mutability of request/session, the pages[] table, and the behaviors/side-effects of the POST/session-related helpers that can change the values tested by those expressions.
